user_input: What is the purpose of the ALERT pin on the PANJIT PJ85775?
response: The ALERT pin on the PANJIT PJ85775 is an open-drain output used to indicate an alert when the measured temperature goes over or under the user-programmed high and low temperature limits.
retrieved_contexts: It has ALERT logic output pin with open drain structure, which is selectable for active low or high by programming.
FUNCTIONAL PIN DESCRIPTION: ALERT: To Indicate ALERT of over or under Temperature programmed by setting THIGH/TLOW register...
ALERT Output: ALERT pin is output with open drain...
ALERT response is compatible with SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA).
If the measured temperature meets or exceeds the high-limit temperature, ALERT pin will be asserted.
reference: The ALERT pin on the PJ85775 signals when temperature exceeds programmed limits.

user_input: What is the maximum I2C communication speed supported by the PJ85775?

The chip is compatible with both SMBus and I2C.
This chip supports I2C fast mode (400kHz) and standard mode (100kHz).
If the master needs to run at frequencies above 400 kHz in I2C, the master device must issue an HS-mode master code.
reference: The PJ85775 supports I2C communication up to 400 kHz.

user_input: What are the default high and low temperature alert limits for the PANJIT PJ85775?
response: The default low-temperature limit for the PANJIT PJ85775 is 75°C (0x4B00), and the default high-temperature limit is 80°C (0x5000).
retrieved_contexts: Low_Temp_Set, Setup Low Temperature Limitation register: Default Data: 0x4B (1st Byte) 0x00 (2nd Byte)... which means 75°C.
High_Temp_Set, Setup High Temperature Limitation register: Default Data: 0x50 (1st Byte) 0x00 (2nd Byte)... which means 80°C.
Register Map: 0x02 Low_Temp_Set... Default Data 0x4B00
Register Map: 0x03 High_Temp_Set... Default Data 0x5000
The chip compares Temp_Data [0x00] register and High_Temp_Set register [0x03]/Low_Temp_Set register [0x02] in each conversion cycle.
reference: The default alert limits for the PJ85775 are 75°C (low) and 80°C (high).

user_input: What is the function of the 'EM' (Extended Mode) bit in the PJ85775 configuration register?
response: The 'EM' (Extended Mode) bit in the PANJIT PJ85775's configuration register allows the user to select between 12-bit (EM=0) and 13-bit (EM=1) temperature data format, extending the measurement range.
retrieved_contexts: EM, Extended Mode bit: This bit allows user to select 12-bit (EM=0) or 13-bit (EM=1) temperature data.
When EM bit is set as '1', the temperature resolution is still 0.0625°C resolution. However, the expression range is extended from -255 to +255.
if set EM as '1', Temp data is expressed in 13-bit format.
The default for EM bit is '0' after Power-on reset.
Table-2. 13-bit Temperature Data (EM bit = 1)
reference: The 'EM' bit in the PJ85775 selects between 12-bit and 13-bit temperature data formats.

user_input: What are the four selectable temperature conversion rates for the PANJIT PJ85775?
response: The four selectable temperature conversion rates for the PANJIT PJ85775 are 8.0Hz, 4.0Hz, 1.0Hz, and 0.25Hz.
retrieved_contexts: CR1, CR0, Conversion Rate Selection bits: These 2 bits allow user to setup different conversion rate for temperature.
Conversion Rate Table: 00: 8.0Hz / 0.125s (default), 01: 4.0Hz / 0.25s, 10: 1.0Hz / 1.0s, 11: 0.25Hz / 4.0s.
Config, Configuration Setup register: CR1, CR0
The default is 00 after POR, meaning the conversion rate is 8Hz.
This feature is used for reducing power consumption when continuous temperature monitoring is not necessary.
reference: The selectable conversion rates for the PJ85775 are 8.0Hz, 4.0Hz, 1.0Hz, and 0.25Hz.

user_input: How does the 'Fault Queue' feature of the PJ85775 work?
response: The 'Fault Queue' feature of the PANJIT PJ85775 allows the user to set the number of consecutive fault conditions (1, 2, 4, or 6) that must occur before the ALERT pin is triggered, which helps to prevent false alerts from noise.
retrieved_contexts: F1, F0, Fault Queue bits: These 2 bits are used to setup the number of fault conditions to trigger alert.
This feature is used to prevent a false alert, which is immune to certain noise in application.
Fault Queue Number Table: 00: 1 (default), 01: 2, 10: 4, 11: 6.
The default is 00 after POR, which means one time fault.
The ALERT pin will becomes active if the monitored temperature equals or exceeds the value setup...for a consecutive number of faults according to setup by F1 and F0 bits.
reference: The PJ85775's 'Fault Queue' requires a set number of consecutive temperature faults (1, 2, 4, or 6) before triggering an alert.

user_input: What is the difference between Comparator Mode and Interrupt Mode for the PJ85775's ALERT pin?
response: In Comparator Mode, the ALERT pin stays active as long as the temperature is above the high limit and deactivates only when it drops below the low limit. In Interrupt Mode, the ALERT pin becomes active when the high limit is exceeded and stays active until it is cleared by a read operation or an SMBus Alert Response.
retrieved_contexts: ALTM, Alert Operation Mode bit: This bit allows user to select ALERT pin operation mode: Comparator Mode or Interrupt Mode.
Comparator mode (ALTM=0): The ALERT pin keeps active until the temperature falls below the value setup in Low_Temp_Set [0x02] register.
Interrupt mode (ALTM=1): The ALERT pin keeps active until a read operation of any register happens or the chip responds to SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA) successfully.
The default is 0 after POR to select Comparator Mode.
When ALERT pin is cleared (in interrupt mode), it will become active again only when the temperature falls below the value setup in Low_Temp_Set register.
reference: In Comparator Mode, the PJ85775's ALERT pin follows the temperature relative to high/low limits, while in Interrupt Mode it latches until cleared by a read command.

user_input: Does the PANJIT PJ85775 sensor support the SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA)?
response: Yes, the PANJIT PJ85775 supports the SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA) feature when operating in interrupt mode (ALTM=1).
retrieved_contexts: Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
ALERT response is compatible with SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA).
SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA): The chip supports the SMBus alert function feature.
When the master detects that the ALERT pin is asserted, it will send Alert Response Address (ARA) to general address (0001, 1001b).
If the chip wins the arbitration, ALERT pin is released after completion of SMBus ARA command.
reference: Yes, the PJ85775 supports SMBus ARA in interrupt mode.

user_input: What is the temperature conversion time for the PJ85775?

When the device is in shutdown mode, setting this bit as '1' will trigger a single time temperature conversion.
CR1, CR0, Conversion Rate Selection bits
The temperature measurement data is stored in read only temperature register.
The chip can sense temperature and convert it into digital data by a 12-bit ADC.
reference: The conversion time for the PJ85775 is typically 30 ms.

user_input: What is the recommended bypass capacitor for the VCC pin of the PJ85775?
response: It is recommended to use a 0.1µF low ESR ceramic capacitor between the VCC and GND pins for the PANJIT PJ85775.
retrieved_contexts: FUNCTIONAL PIN DESCRIPTION: VCC Power supply input pin, using 0.1uF low ESR ceramic capacitor to ground
APPLICATION SCHEMATIC: CIN 0.1uF
Noise between VCC and GND: It is very necessary to place a low ESR ceramic cap (CIN) between VCC and GND pin to filter digital noise.
The recommended capacitance is 0.1 uF.
This filter cap should be placed as close as possible to the chip.
reference: A 0.1µF low ESR ceramic capacitor is the recommended bypass capacitor for the PJ85775.

user_input: What does the 'OS' (One Shot) bit do in the PJ85775 configuration?
response: When the PANJIT PJ85775 is in shutdown mode, setting the 'OS' (One Shot) bit to '1' triggers a single temperature conversion, after which the device returns to shutdown mode to conserve power.
retrieved_contexts: OS, One shot Conversion bit: When the device is in shutdown mode, setting this bit as '1' will trigger a single time temperature conversion.
The device returns to shutdown mode once it completes the single conversion.
This feature is used for reducing power consumption when continuous temperature monitoring is not necessary.
During the conversion, the OS bit reads as '0'.
Config, Configuration Setup register: OS
reference: The 'OS' bit in the PJ85775 initiates a single temperature measurement from shutdown mode.

Off = Power Off / Modbus communications are not present

user_input: What types of gases can the Bosch BME690 sensor detect?
response: The Bosch BME690 gas sensor can detect Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), volatile sulfur compounds (VSCs), and other gases like carbon monoxide and hydrogen.
retrieved_contexts: The gas sensor can detect Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), volatile sulfur compounds (VSCs) and other gases such as carbon monoxide and hydrogen.
The BME690 is a metal oxide-based sensor that detects gases by adsorption... The BME690 reacts to most volatile compounds.
The BME690 is capable of measuring the sum of VOCs/contaminants in the surrounding air.
In standard configuration, the presence of VSCs is being detected as indicator for e.g. bacteria growth.
Bad breath or spoiled food detection based on the measurement of volatile sulfur compounds, which are an indicator of bacteria growth.
reference: The Bosch BME690 can detect VOCs, VSCs, carbon monoxide, and hydrogen.

Operating Range: 0-100% r.H.
The BME690 is the gas sensor with... integrated high-linearity and high-accuracy pressure, humidity and temperature sensors.
reference: The accuracy tolerance of the BME690's humidity sensor is ±3% r.H.

Reduced power consumption for LP and ULP mode compared to BME680/BME688
The BME690 is especially developed for mobile & connected applications where size and low power consumption are critical requirements.
reference: The Bosch BME690 consumes 50 µA (or 0.05 mA) in ultra-low power (ULP) mode.

user_input: What digital interfaces does the Bosch BME690 support?
response: The Bosch BME690 supports both I2C (up to 3.4 MHz) and SPI (3 and 4 wire, up to 10 MHz) digital interfaces.
retrieved_contexts: Key features: Digital interface: I2C (up to 3.4 MHz) and SPI (3 and 4 wire, up to 10 MHz)
The sensor supports the I2C and SPI digital interfaces, where it acts as a slave for both protocols.
The I2C interface supports the Standard, Fast and High Speed modes.
The SPI interface supports both SPI mode '00' and mode '11' in 4-wire and 3-wire configuration.
Interface selection is done automatically based on CSB (chip select) status.
reference: The Bosch BME690 supports I2C and SPI (3 and 4 wire) interfaces.

user_input: What are some of the key outputs provided by the BSEC software for the BME690?
response: The BSEC software for the BME690 provides several key outputs, including an Index for Air Quality (IAQ), bVOC-equivalents (ppm), CO2-equivalents (ppm), Gas scan result (%), and an Intensity level.
retrieved_contexts: Key parameters for gas sensor: Output data processing: Major direct outputs: Index for Air Quality (IAQ), bVOC- & CO2-equivalents (ppm), Gas scan result (%) & Intensity level
The BSEC provides numerous useful outputs (see Table 20), e.g. an Index for Air Quality (IAQ), bVOC- & CO2-equivalents (ppm) and Gas scan results (%).
BSEC outputs: IAQ (0-500), Static IAQ, CO2 equivalent (ppm), b-VOC equivalent (ppm), TVOC equivalent (ppb).
The IAQ output is an index that can have values between 0 and 500.
The BME AI-Studio tool enables customers to train the BME690 gas scanner on their specific application.
reference: Key outputs of the BSEC software for the BME690 include Index for Air Quality (IAQ), CO2 equivalent (ppm), and b-VOC equivalent (ppm).

user_input: What are the different BSEC software power modes for the BME690 gas sensor?
response: The BSEC software for the BME690 gas sensor supports four power modes: Gas Scan mode (scan), Ultra-low power (ULP) mode, Low power (LP) mode, and Continuous (CONT) mode.
retrieved_contexts: BSEC gas sensor power-modes Table: Standard gas scan mode (scan), Ultra-low power mode (ULP), Low power mode (LP), Continuous mode...
ULP mode is designed for battery-powered and/or frequency-coupled devices...
LP mode that is designed for interactive applications...
Gas Scan mode (scan) is designed for interactive applications where selectivity of traget gases are needed...
Continuous (CONT) mode provides an update rate of 1 Hz and shall only be used short-term...

user_input: Can the Bosch BME690 gas scanner be customized, and if so, how?

user_input: Does the BME690 have an internal filter, and which measurements does it affect?
response: Yes, the Bosch BME690 features an internal IIR (Infinite Impulse Response) filter. It applies to the temperature and pressure data to suppress short-term fluctuations, but not to the humidity and gas data.
retrieved_contexts: IIR filter: The environmental pressure is subject to many short-term changes...the BME690 features an internal IIR filter.
It effectively reduces the bandwidth of the temperature and pressure output signals...
IIR filter applies to temperature and pressure data but not to humidity and gas data.
...the humidity and gas values inside the sensor does not fluctuate rapidly and does not require low pass filtering.
When the IIR filter is enabled, the temperature resolution is 20 bit.
reference: Yes, the BME690 has an internal IIR filter that applies to temperature and pressure data only.

user_input: What is the purpose of the integrated heater in the BME690's gas sensor?
response: The integrated heater in the Bosch BME690's gas sensor is used to heat the metal oxide gas sensitive layer to various target temperatures (typically 200°C to 400°C). Operating at different temperatures enables the sensor to have different sensitivities, creating a unique 'fingerprint' to help classify different gas compositions.
retrieved_contexts: Gas sensor heating and measurement: Heating the gas sensor hot plate to a target temperature (typically between 200°C and 400°C)...

Selectivity: Operating the metal oxide layer of the gas sensor at different temperatures enable measuring with different sensitivities and can create a unique fingerprint for numerous gas compositions.
The standard heater profile...consists of 10 heater temperature steps.
Up to 10 different hot plate temperature set points can be configured...
The internal heater control loop operates on the resistance of the heater structure.
reference: The heater in the BME690 changes the temperature of the gas-sensitive layer to enable classification of different gases.
